questions.original_passage: BR Scores vs. T-Scores: T-scores assume a normal distribution and compare an individual to a normative mean. BR scores are calibrated to the actual prevalence of disorders in the target population. Because personality disorders vary in prevalence, using BR scores helps avoid overdiagnosis of rare disorders and underdiagnosis of common ones
questions.modified_passage: BR Scores vs. T-Scores: T-scores assume a normal distribution and compare an individual to a normative mean. BR scores are calibrated to the actual prevalence of disorders in the target population. Because personality disorders vary in prevalence, using BR scores helps avoid overdiagnosis of common disorders and underdiagnosis of rare ones
questions.error_original: overdiagnosis of common disorders and underdiagnosis of rare ones
questions.error_correct: overdiagnosis of rare disorders and underdiagnosis of common ones
options: The passage incorrectly states that T-scores assume a normal distribution; they actually assume a skewed distribution
The passage incorrectly states that BR scores are calibrated to the actual prevalence of disorders; they are calibrated to standard deviation units
The passage incorrectly states overdiagnosis of common disorders and underdiagnosis of rare ones; it should say overdiagnosis of rare disorders and underdiagnosis of common ones
The passage incorrectly states that T-scores compare an individual to a normative mean; they compare an individual to a criterion-referenced standard
questions.explanation: The passage reversed the key relationship. The advantage of BR (Base Rate) scores is that they help avoid overdiagnosis of RARE disorders and underdiagnosis of COMMON ones. Without base rate calibration, instruments using standard T-scores may over-identify rare conditions and under-identify prevalent ones because the cutoff thresholds are not adjusted for actual prevalence rates. The modified passage swapped 'rare' and 'common,' reversing this important diagnostic concept.

questions.original_passage: Interests + developmental context: Consider the client's age, life stage, career development stage (Super's Life-Span model), and prior work experiences when interpreting interest profiles.
questions.modified_passage: Interests + developmental context: Consider the client's age, life stage, career development stage (Holland's Life-Span model), and prior work experiences when interpreting interest profiles.
options: The passage incorrectly states 'prior work experiences'; it should say 'prior educational experiences'
The passage incorrectly states 'Holland's Life-Span model'; it should say 'Super's Life-Span model'
The passage incorrectly states 'interest profiles'; it should say 'personality profiles'
The passage incorrectly states 'career development stage'; it should say 'career exploration stage'
questions.explanation: The Life-Span, Life-Space model of career development was proposed by Donald Super, not John Holland. Holland is known for his RIASEC model of vocational interests and personality types. Super's theory emphasizes developmental stages across the lifespan (Growth, Exploration, Establishment, Maintenance, and Disengagement) and the various life roles individuals occupy. The passage incorrectly attributes this model to Holland.

questions.section: Grade Equivalents, Age Equivalents, and Their Limitations
questions.original_passage: Grade equivalent (GE) scores express performance in terms of the grade level at which the raw score represents average performance. Age equivalent (AE) scores express performance as the age at which the raw score is average. Both are among the most frequently misinterpreted score types
questions.modified_passage: Grade equivalent (GE) scores express performance in terms of the grade level at which the raw score represents average performance. Age equivalent (AE) scores express performance as the age at which the raw score is median. Both are among the most frequently misinterpreted score types.
options: The passage incorrectly states that GE scores represent 'average performance'; it should say 'median performance'
The passage incorrectly states that AE scores express performance as the age at which the raw score is 'median'; it should say 'average'
The passage incorrectly states that these are 'the most frequently misinterpreted score types'; it should say 'the least frequently misinterpreted score types'
The passage incorrectly states that GE scores express performance in terms of 'grade level'; it should say 'stanine level'
questions.explanation: The passage introduced an error by changing 'average' to 'median' in the description of Age Equivalent (AE) scores. AE scores express performance as the age at which the raw score is average (i.e., the mean performance for that age group), not the median. While the distinction between mean and median can seem subtle, in the standard definition of age equivalents used in psychometric literature, the score reflects average (mean) performance for a given age. The other options describe changes that were not actually made in the passage.

questions.original_passage: A percentile rank of 50 corresponds to the mean (z = 0) in a normal distribution
questions.modified_passage: A percentile rank of 50 corresponds to the mean (z = 1) in a normal distribution
options: The passage incorrectly states that a percentile rank of 50 corresponds to the mean; it should say the median
The passage incorrectly states z = 1; it should say z = 0
The passage incorrectly states a percentile rank of 50; it should say a percentile rank of 68
The passage incorrectly states 'normal distribution'; it should say 'skewed distribution'
questions.explanation: The error introduced was changing the z-score from 0 to 1. In a normal distribution, a percentile rank of 50 corresponds to the center of the distribution, which is a z-score of 0 (not 1). A z-score of 1 would correspond to approximately the 84th percentile. Note that the first distractor ('mean' should be 'median') is plausible-sounding but not actually an error here, because in a perfectly normal distribution the mean and the median are identical, so stating it corresponds to the mean is not incorrect.

questions.original_passage: Standard 2.01 requires psychologists to provide services within the boundaries of their competence, based on their education, training, supervised experience, consultation, study, or professional experience. In assessment, this means:
questions.modified_passage: Standard 2.04 requires psychologists to provide services within the boundaries of their competence, based on their education, training, supervised experience, consultation, study, or professional experience. In assessment, this means:
options: The passage incorrectly states that competence is based on 'supervised experience'; it should say 'independent experience'
The passage incorrectly states 'Standard 2.04'; it should say 'Standard 2.01'
The passage incorrectly states 'boundaries of their competence'; it should say 'scope of their practice'
The passage incorrectly states 'consultation, study, or professional experience'; it should say 'consultation, research, or professional experience'
questions.explanation: The APA Ethics Code Standard that addresses practicing within the boundaries of competence is Standard 2.01 ('Boundaries of Competence'), not Standard 2.04. Standard 2.04 addresses 'Bases for Scientific and Professional Judgments.' The other options describe changes that were not actually made in the passage — the original passage correctly uses 'supervised experience,' 'boundaries of their competence,' and 'consultation, study, or professional experience.'

questions.original_passage: Motivational Interviewing (Miller & Rollnick, 1991, 2013) is a client-centered, directive therapeutic style designed to enhance intrinsic motivation for change by exploring and resolving ambivalence. MI is particularly effective for substance use disorders but is applied broadly across health behavior change
questions.modified_passage: Motivational Interviewing (Miller & Rollnick, 1991, 2013) is a client-centered, directive therapeutic style designed to enhance extrinsic motivation for change by exploring and resolving ambivalence. MI is particularly effective for substance use disorders but is applied broadly across health behavior change
options: The passage incorrectly states MI is 'client-centered'; it should say 'therapist-centered'
The passage incorrectly states 'extrinsic motivation'; it should say 'intrinsic motivation'
The passage incorrectly states the original year as '1991'; it should say '1983'
The passage incorrectly states MI is 'directive'; it should say 'non-directive'
questions.explanation: The passage was modified to say 'extrinsic motivation' instead of the correct term 'intrinsic motivation.' A core principle of Motivational Interviewing is that it aims to enhance a client's intrinsic (internal) motivation for change, not extrinsic (external) motivation. The original publication by Miller & Rollnick (1991) and subsequent editions explicitly describe MI as designed to elicit and strengthen the client's own internal reasons for change. The other options describe elements that are actually correct in the passage: MI is indeed described as both 'client-centered' and 'directive,' and the 1991 date is accurate for the first edition of the foundational text.

questions.original_passage: Scoring categories: Location (W = whole, D = common detail, Dd = unusual detail), Determinants (form, color, shading, movement), Content (human, animal, anatomy, etc.), Popular responses, Organizational Activity (Z-scores)
questions.modified_passage: Scoring categories: Location (W = whole, D = common detail, Dd = unusual detail), Determinants (form, color, shading, movement), Content (human, animal, anatomy, etc.), Popular responses, Organizational Activity (T-scores)
options: The passage incorrectly states that D = common detail; it should say D = dominant detail
The passage incorrectly states that Dd = unusual detail; it should say Dd = uncommon detail
The passage incorrectly states T-scores for Organizational Activity; it should say Z-scores
The passage incorrectly lists shading as a Determinant; it should say texture
questions.explanation: In Exner's Comprehensive System, Organizational Activity is scored using Z-scores, not T-scores. T-scores are a type of standardized score used in other psychometric contexts (e.g., MMPI), but in the Rorschach Comprehensive System, the organizational activity of a response is specifically quantified using Z-scores, which reflect the cognitive effort involved in organizing the blot into a meaningful percept.

questions.original_passage: Coloured Progressive Matrices (CPM): Easier version for children ages 5-11 and individuals with cognitive impairment. Uses colored backgrounds to maintain attention.
questions.modified_passage: Coloured Progressive Matrices (CPM): Easier version for children ages 3-11 and individuals with cognitive impairment. Uses colored backgrounds to maintain attention.
options: The passage incorrectly states the CPM is for 'individuals with cognitive impairment'; it should say 'individuals with visual impairment'
The passage incorrectly states the CPM 'uses colored backgrounds to maintain attention'; it should say 'uses colored backgrounds to reduce difficulty'
The passage incorrectly states the age range as 'ages 3-11'; it should say 'ages 5-11'
The passage incorrectly describes the CPM as an 'easier version'; it should say 'advanced version'
questions.explanation: The original passage specifies that the Coloured Progressive Matrices (CPM) is designed for children ages 5-11, not ages 3-11. The age range was subtly altered from 5-11 to 3-11, which is a number/value change error. The CPM is indeed an easier version of the Raven's Progressive Matrices, it is designed for individuals with cognitive impairment, and it does use colored backgrounds to maintain attention—all of those facts are correct as stated.

questions.original_passage: Organizational approach: A piecemeal or fragmented approach to copying (focusing on details rather than the global structure) is associated with executive dysfunction and may also predict poor recall
questions.modified_passage: Organizational approach: A piecemeal or fragmented approach to copying (focusing on details rather than the global structure) is associated with executive dysfunction and may also predict poor recognition
options: The passage incorrectly states 'executive dysfunction'; it should say 'visuospatial dysfunction'
The passage incorrectly states 'global structure'; it should say 'local structure'
The passage incorrectly states 'poor recognition'; it should say 'poor recall'
The passage incorrectly states 'fragmented approach'; it should say 'holistic approach'
questions.explanation: The original passage states that a piecemeal or fragmented approach to copying 'may also predict poor recall.' The modified passage incorrectly changed 'recall' to 'recognition.' In neuropsychological assessment, particularly with figure-copying tasks like the Rey Complex Figure Test, a fragmented organizational approach is specifically associated with poor recall performance, not poor recognition. Recognition memory is a different and less demanding memory process that is not what is predicted by disorganized copying strategy.

questions.original_passage: The behavioral interview is a fundamental assessment tool for gathering information about target behaviors, their antecedents, consequences, and maintaining variables. Behavioral interviews can be unstructured (open-ended, flexible format guided by clinical judgment) or structured (predetermined questions asked in a standardized order)
questions.modified_passage: The behavioral interview is a fundamental assessment tool for gathering information about target behaviors, their antecedents, consequences, and mediating variables. Behavioral interviews can be unstructured (open-ended, flexible format guided by clinical judgment) or structured (predetermined questions asked in a standardized order)
options: The passage incorrectly states 'unstructured' for the open-ended format; it should say 'semi-structured'
The passage incorrectly states 'mediating variables'; it should say 'maintaining variables'
The passage incorrectly states 'antecedents'; it should say 'precipitants'
The passage incorrectly states 'standardized order'; it should say 'randomized order'
questions.explanation: The passage replaced the term 'maintaining variables' with 'mediating variables.' In behavioral assessment, the behavioral interview specifically focuses on identifying maintaining variables — the factors that sustain or perpetuate target behaviors over time. 'Mediating variables' is a related but distinct statistical/research concept referring to variables that explain the mechanism through which an independent variable affects a dependent variable. The correct term in the context of behavioral interviews and functional analysis is 'maintaining variables.'

questions.original_passage: Seemingly Irrelevant Decisions (SIDs): Minor choices that increase relapse risk. Part of the relapse prevention model.
questions.modified_passage: Seemingly Irrelevant Decisions (SIDs): Minor choices that decrease relapse risk. Part of the relapse prevention model.
options: The passage incorrectly states SIDs are part of the relapse prevention model; they are actually part of the stages of change model
The passage incorrectly states that SIDs are 'minor' choices; they should be described as 'major' choices
The passage incorrectly states that SIDs decrease relapse risk; it should say they increase relapse risk
The passage incorrectly states the acronym SIDs stands for 'Seemingly Irrelevant Decisions'; it should be 'Superficially Irrelevant Decisions'
questions.explanation: The defining characteristic of Seemingly Irrelevant Decisions (SIDs) in the relapse prevention model is that they are minor, apparently harmless choices that actually INCREASE the risk of relapse. For example, an individual in recovery might decide to walk past a bar 'just because it's a shorter route,' which incrementally moves them closer to a high-risk situation. The passage erroneously states that SIDs 'decrease' relapse risk, which reverses the core concept.

questions.original_passage: Failure to maintain set: Making an error after 5+ consecutive correct sorts within a category (suggests attentional lapses)
questions.modified_passage: Failure to maintain set: Making an error after 3+ consecutive correct sorts within a category (suggests attentional lapses)
options: The passage incorrectly states that this suggests attentional lapses; it should say perseverative tendencies
The passage incorrectly states 3+ consecutive correct sorts; it should say 5+ consecutive correct sorts
The passage incorrectly states 'within a category'; it should say 'across categories'
The passage incorrectly states 'failure to maintain set'; it should say 'failure to shift set'
questions.explanation: On the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST), 'Failure to Maintain Set' is defined as making an error after 5 or more consecutive correct sorts within a category, suggesting attentional lapses. The passage incorrectly changed this threshold from 5+ to 3+. The other options describe changes that were not made: the score does suggest attentional lapses (not perseverative tendencies), it does occur within a category, and the correct term is 'failure to maintain set' (not 'failure to shift set').

questions.original_passage: Confidence interval width: Wider confidence intervals indicate less precise measurement (lower reliability or larger SD). Narrower intervals indicate more precise measurement.
questions.modified_passage: Confidence interval width: Wider confidence intervals indicate less precise measurement (lower reliability or smaller SD). Narrower intervals indicate more precise measurement.
options: The passage incorrectly states 'less precise measurement'; it should say 'more precise measurement'
The passage incorrectly states 'lower reliability'; it should say 'higher reliability'
The passage incorrectly states 'smaller SD'; it should say 'larger SD'
The passage incorrectly states 'Narrower intervals indicate more precise measurement'; it should say 'Narrower intervals indicate less precise measurement'
questions.explanation: The original passage correctly states that wider confidence intervals are associated with a 'larger SD' (standard deviation). A larger standard deviation contributes to a wider standard error of measurement (SEM), which in turn produces wider confidence intervals. The modified passage incorrectly changed 'larger SD' to 'smaller SD,' reversing the relationship. A smaller SD would actually contribute to narrower (more precise) confidence intervals, not wider ones.

questions.original_passage: TFP (Kernberg, Yeomans, & Clarkin) is a psychodynamic treatment that uses the analysis of transference patterns to restructure pathological object relations . The treatment assumes that BPD results from the predominance of splitting and other primitive defenses that prevent the integration of positive and negative representations of self and others. TFP aims to integrate these split representations through systematic analysis of how they manifest in the therapeutic relationship. TFP is a twice-weekly, individual treatment
questions.modified_passage: TFP (Kernberg, Yeomans, & Clarkin) is a psychodynamic treatment that uses the analysis of transference patterns to restructure pathological object relations. The treatment assumes that BPD results from the predominance of projection and other primitive defenses that prevent the integration of positive and negative representations of self and others. TFP aims to integrate these split representations through systematic analysis of how they manifest in the therapeutic relationship. TFP is a twice-weekly, individual treatment.
options: The passage incorrectly states TFP is a 'twice-weekly' treatment; it should say 'once-weekly'
The passage incorrectly states TFP aims to 'integrate' split representations; it should say 'differentiate'
The passage incorrectly states the predominance of 'projection'; it should say 'splitting'
The passage incorrectly states TFP restructures 'pathological object relations'; it should say 'maladaptive attachment schemas'
questions.explanation: The original passage identifies 'splitting' as the predominant primitive defense in the TFP model of BPD. Splitting is the core defense mechanism in Kernberg's object relations theory of borderline personality organization, referring to the inability to integrate positive and negative representations of self and others. The modified passage substituted 'projection' for 'splitting.' While projection is indeed a primitive defense, it is splitting that is considered the predominant and foundational defense in TFP's theoretical framework for understanding BPD.

questions.original_passage: KABC-II: Dual interpretive models. CHC model yields FCI (includes crystallized). Luria model yields MPI (excludes crystallized). Use Luria/MPI for culturally/linguistically diverse children
questions.modified_passage: KABC-II: Dual interpretive models. CHC model yields MPI (includes crystallized). Luria model yields FCI (excludes crystallized). Use Luria/FCI for culturally/linguistically diverse children
questions.error_original: CHC model yields MPI (includes crystallized). Luria model yields FCI (excludes crystallized)
questions.error_correct: CHC model yields FCI (includes crystallized). Luria model yields MPI (excludes crystallized)
options: The passage incorrectly states that the Luria model is recommended for culturally/linguistically diverse children; it should say the CHC model is recommended
The passage incorrectly swaps the score names: CHC model yields MPI and Luria model yields FCI; it should say CHC yields FCI and Luria yields MPI
The passage incorrectly states the KABC-II has dual interpretive models; it should say it has a single unified model
The passage incorrectly states crystallized ability is excluded from one model; both models include crystallized ability
questions.explanation: The passage swapped FCI and MPI between the two models. In the KABC-II, the CHC (Cattell-Horn-Carroll) model yields the Fluid-Crystallized Index (FCI), which includes crystallized ability. The Luria model yields the Mental Processing Index (MPI), which excludes crystallized ability. The MPI/Luria model is recommended for culturally and linguistically diverse children precisely because it excludes crystallized measures that may be culturally biased.

questions.original_passage: Test user qualifications: Tests are classified by user qualification levels (A, B, C or equivalent). Level C tests (e.g., IQ tests, personality inventories) require doctoral-level training. Improper use by unqualified individuals is an ethical concern.
questions.modified_passage: Test user qualifications: Tests are classified by user qualification levels (A, B, C or equivalent). Level B tests (e.g., IQ tests, personality inventories) require doctoral-level training. Improper use by unqualified individuals is an ethical concern.
options: The passage incorrectly states that improper use is an 'ethical concern'; it should say 'legal concern'
The passage incorrectly states 'Level B tests' require doctoral-level training; it should say 'Level C tests'
The passage incorrectly states qualification levels are 'A, B, C'; they should be '1, 2, 3'
The passage incorrectly states that IQ tests require 'doctoral-level training'; they only require 'master's-level training'
questions.explanation: The error introduced was changing 'Level C tests' to 'Level B tests.' In the standard test user qualification classification system, Level C tests (such as individually administered IQ tests and personality inventories like projective tests) require the highest level of training—doctoral-level training in psychology. Level B tests require a lower level of qualification (typically master's-level training or relevant coursework). The passage incorrectly attributes doctoral-level requirements to Level B tests instead of Level C tests.

questions.original_passage: Raymond Cattell's Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire was developed through lexical factor analysis and identifies 16 primary personality factors (e.g., Warmth, Reasoning, Emotional Stability, Dominance) and 5 global factors. It is used primarily in personnel selection and occupational settings rather than clinical diagnosis
questions.modified_passage: Raymond Cattell's Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire was developed through lexical factor analysis and identifies 16 primary personality factors (e.g., Warmth, Reasoning, Emotional Stability, Dominance) and 3 global factors. It is used primarily in personnel selection and occupational settings rather than clinical diagnosis.
options: The passage incorrectly states the 16PF was developed through lexical factor analysis; it should say criterion-keyed analysis
The passage incorrectly states the 16PF identifies 16 primary personality factors; it should say 15 primary personality factors
The passage incorrectly states the 16PF has 3 global factors; it should say 5 global factors
The passage incorrectly states the 16PF is used primarily in personnel selection; it should say it is used primarily in clinical diagnosis
questions.explanation: The passage was modified to state that the 16PF identifies '3 global factors' when in fact it identifies 5 global factors. The five global factors (also called second-order or global factors) are Extraversion, Anxiety, Tough-Mindedness, Independence, and Self-Control. The other options describe changes that were not actually made to the passage: the 16PF was indeed developed using lexical factor analysis, it does identify 16 primary factors, and it is indeed used primarily in personnel selection and occupational settings rather than clinical diagnosis.

questions.original_passage: Alliance Ruptures and Repair: Alliance ruptures are breakdowns in the collaborative relationship, manifested as disagreements about tasks or goals, or strains in the bond. Ruptures can be withdrawal (client disengages, becomes compliant but not invested) or confrontation (client expresses dissatisfaction or hostility). Successful repair of ruptures is associated with improved outcomes and may be a key mechanism of therapeutic change, particularly for clients with interpersonal difficulties
questions.modified_passage: Alliance Ruptures and Repair: Alliance ruptures are breakdowns in the collaborative relationship, manifested as disagreements about tasks or goals, or strains in the bond. Ruptures can be withdrawal (client disengages, becomes compliant but not invested) or confrontation (client expresses dissatisfaction or hostility). Successful repair of ruptures is associated with improved outcomes and may be a key mechanism of therapeutic change, particularly for clients with cognitive distortions
options: The passage incorrectly states that ruptures can be 'withdrawal'; it should say 'avoidance'
The passage incorrectly states that ruptures are 'breakdowns in the collaborative relationship'; it should say 'breakdowns in the corrective emotional experience'
The passage incorrectly states rupture repair is particularly relevant for clients with 'cognitive distortions'; it should say 'interpersonal difficulties'
The passage incorrectly states that confrontation involves the client expressing 'dissatisfaction or hostility'; it should say 'dissatisfaction or ambivalence'
questions.explanation: The original passage states that successful repair of ruptures is particularly important for clients with 'interpersonal difficulties,' which makes conceptual sense given that alliance ruptures are inherently interpersonal events. The modified passage substituted 'cognitive distortions,' which is a term more associated with cognitive therapy models (e.g., Beck's cognitive therapy) and does not accurately reflect the interpersonal focus of alliance rupture and repair research.

questions.original_passage: Forensic assessment: Primary obligation is to referral source, not examinee. Informed consent must be obtained even when assessment is mandated.
questions.modified_passage: Forensic assessment: Primary obligation is to referral source, not examinee. Informed consent must be obtained only when assessment is voluntary.
options: The passage incorrectly states the primary obligation is to the referral source; it should say the primary obligation is to the examinee
The passage incorrectly states informed consent must be obtained only when assessment is voluntary; it should say even when assessment is mandated
The passage incorrectly states informed consent must be obtained; it should say informed assent must be obtained
The passage incorrectly refers to forensic assessment; it should say therapeutic assessment
questions.explanation: The original passage correctly states that informed consent must be obtained 'even when assessment is mandated.' The modified passage changed this to 'only when assessment is voluntary,' which is factually incorrect. Ethical guidelines (e.g., APA Ethical Principles, Standard 9.03) require that informed consent — or at minimum notification of the nature and purpose of the evaluation — be provided even in mandated or court-ordered forensic assessments. The other options describe changes that were not actually made to the passage.

questions.original_passage: Base rates in forensic assessment: Prevalence of the condition being assessed (e.g., malingering, violence) affects predictive accuracy. Even accurate tests produce many false positives when base rates are low.
questions.modified_passage: Base rates in forensic assessment: Prevalence of the condition being assessed (e.g., malingering, violence) affects predictive accuracy. Even accurate tests produce many false negatives when base rates are low.
options: The passage incorrectly states 'predictive accuracy'; it should say 'concurrent validity'
The passage incorrectly states 'false negatives'; it should say 'false positives'
The passage incorrectly states 'base rates are low'; it should say 'base rates are high'
The passage incorrectly states 'malingering, violence'; it should say 'malingering, psychopathy'
questions.explanation: The passage incorrectly states that even accurate tests produce many 'false negatives' when base rates are low. The correct statement is that even accurate tests produce many 'false positives' when base rates are low. This is a well-established principle in forensic assessment: when the base rate of a condition is low (i.e., most people in the sample do not have the condition), even a test with high sensitivity and specificity will generate a disproportionate number of false positives relative to true positives. This is because the large number of people without the condition will produce more false positive results than the small number of people with the condition will produce true positives.

questions.original_passage: Working Memory Index (WMI): Digit Span, Arithmetic — taps short-term auditory memory and mental manipulation
questions.modified_passage: Working Memory Index (WMI): Digit Span, Arithmetic — taps long-term auditory memory and mental manipulation
options: The passage incorrectly lists Arithmetic as a WMI subtest; it should say Letter-Number Sequencing
The passage incorrectly states long-term auditory memory; it should say short-term auditory memory
The passage incorrectly abbreviates Working Memory Index as WMI; it should be WM
The passage incorrectly lists Digit Span as a WMI subtest; it should say Symbol Search
questions.explanation: The passage was modified to say 'long-term auditory memory' instead of the correct 'short-term auditory memory.' The Working Memory Index (WMI) on the WAIS-IV, composed of Digit Span and Arithmetic, specifically measures short-term auditory memory and mental manipulation — not long-term memory. Long-term memory involves the retention of information over extended periods, which is not what these subtests assess.

questions.original_passage: MBCT mechanism: Teaches decentering — the ability to observe thoughts as mental events rather than reality. This prevents the "depressive interlock" where negative mood activates negative thinking patterns that trigger relapse.
questions.modified_passage: MBCT mechanism: Teaches decentering — the ability to observe thoughts as mental events rather than reality. This prevents the "depressive interlock" where negative mood activates negative thinking patterns that trigger remission.
options: The passage incorrectly states 'decentering'; it should say 'defusion'
The passage incorrectly states 'mental events'; it should say 'cognitive distortions'
The passage incorrectly states 'trigger remission'; it should say 'trigger relapse'
The passage incorrectly states 'negative mood activates negative thinking patterns'; it should say 'negative thinking patterns activate negative mood'
questions.explanation: The passage incorrectly uses the word 'remission' (which refers to a reduction or disappearance of symptoms) when it should say 'relapse' (a return of depressive symptoms). MBCT is specifically designed to prevent depressive relapse by interrupting the 'depressive interlock' cycle in which negative mood reactivates ruminative negative thinking patterns, which in turn deepen the mood disturbance and trigger a full depressive episode. The other options describe plausible-sounding but incorrect changes: 'decentering' is the correct MBCT term (not 'defusion,' which is an ACT concept), 'mental events' is the accurate phrasing used in MBCT literature, and the directionality described — negative mood activating negative thinking patterns — correctly represents the depressive interlock model.

questions.original_passage: R-PAS (Rorschach Performance Assessment System): A newer, empirically based system that addresses normative and psychometric limitations of the CS. R-PAS uses optimized administration with response prompt procedures (R-Optimized) to control response count.
questions.modified_passage: R-PAS (Rorschach Performance Assessment System): A newer, empirically based system that addresses normative and psychometric limitations of the CS. R-PAS uses standardized administration with response prompt procedures (R-Optimized) to control response count.
options: The passage incorrectly states R-PAS addresses 'psychometric' limitations; it should say 'theoretical' limitations
The passage incorrectly states 'standardized administration'; it should say 'optimized administration'
The passage incorrectly states R-PAS uses procedures to 'control response count'; it should say 'control response time'
The passage incorrectly states R-PAS is 'empirically based'; it should say 'theoretically based'
questions.explanation: The original passage specifies that R-PAS uses 'optimized administration' with response prompt procedures (R-Optimized) to control response count. The modified passage incorrectly substituted 'standardized administration' for 'optimized administration.' The term 'optimized' is the specific and correct descriptor used in R-PAS, reflecting the system's distinctive approach to administration that aims to optimize the number of responses given. 'Standardized' sounds plausible but is not the correct technical term associated with R-PAS.

questions.original_passage: Super's career maturity: Readiness to make age-appropriate career decisions. Measured by Career Maturity Inventory (CMI). Precursor to Savickas's career adaptability construct.
questions.modified_passage: Super's career maturity: Readiness to make age-appropriate career decisions. Measured by Career Maturity Inventory (CMI). Precursor to Holland's career adaptability construct.
options: The passage incorrectly states that career maturity involves 'age-appropriate' decisions; it should say 'stage-appropriate' decisions
The passage incorrectly states the construct is 'career maturity'; it should say 'career readiness'
The passage incorrectly states 'Holland's career adaptability construct'; it should say 'Savickas's career adaptability construct'
The passage incorrectly states the measure is the 'Career Maturity Inventory (CMI)'; it should say the 'Career Development Inventory (CDI)'
questions.explanation: The passage incorrectly attributes the career adaptability construct to Holland, when it was actually developed by Savickas. John Holland is known for his RIASEC model of vocational interests, not for the career adaptability construct. Mark Savickas extended Super's career maturity concept into the career adaptability framework as part of career construction theory.

questions.original_passage: Coercion theory (Patterson): Negative reinforcement trap. Child's aversive behavior is reinforced by parent's giving in; parent's giving in is reinforced by cessation of child's behavior. Forms the basis for PMT.
questions.modified_passage: Coercion theory (Patterson): Positive reinforcement trap. Child's aversive behavior is reinforced by parent's giving in; parent's giving in is reinforced by cessation of child's behavior. Forms the basis for PMT.
options: The passage incorrectly states PMT; it should say PCIT
The passage incorrectly states 'Positive reinforcement trap'; it should say 'Negative reinforcement trap'
The passage incorrectly attributes coercion theory to Patterson; it should be attributed to Bandura
The passage incorrectly states that parent's giving in is reinforced by cessation of child's behavior; it should say by escalation of child's behavior
questions.explanation: Coercion theory by Patterson describes a 'negative reinforcement trap,' not a 'positive reinforcement trap.' In this cycle, the parent's giving in is negatively reinforced because the child's aversive behavior stops (removal of an aversive stimulus), and the child's aversive behavior is negatively reinforced because the parent's demands cease. Both parties are reinforced through the removal of something unpleasant, which is the defining feature of negative reinforcement. The passage incorrectly substituted 'Positive' for 'Negative.'

questions.original_passage: Test construction methods: Empirical/criterion keying (MMPI), factor analytic (NEO-PI-R, 16PF), rational/theoretical (PAI), sequential system (MCMI).
questions.modified_passage: Test construction methods: Empirical/criterion keying (MMPI), factor analytic (NEO-PI-R, 16PF), rational/theoretical (PAI), sequential system (MCMI).
questions.error_correct: rational/theoretical construct (PAI) — actually, the PAI uses a construct validation approach, not purely rational/theoretical
options: The passage incorrectly states the MCMI uses a sequential system; it should say it uses empirical/criterion keying
The passage incorrectly states the 16PF uses factor analytic construction; it should say it uses rational/theoretical construction
The passage incorrectly states the NEO-PI-R uses factor analytic construction; it should say it uses empirical/criterion keying
The passage incorrectly states the PAI uses rational/theoretical construction; it should say it uses construct validation
questions.explanation: The PAI (Personality Assessment Inventory) was developed by Leslie Morey using a construct validation approach, not a purely rational/theoretical method. Construct validation involves multiple sequential steps including theoretical considerations, empirical analysis, and validation against external criteria. The rational/theoretical approach (used by tests like the original Woodworth Personal Data Sheet) relies primarily on the test author's theoretical judgment about which items should measure a construct. The PAI's development was more comprehensive, employing a construct validation framework that integrated theoretical, quantitative, and empirical methods across its development stages.

questions.section: Standard 9.09: Test Scoring and Interpretation Services
questions.original_passage: Key Distinction for the EPPP: Test DATA is generally released to clients upon request (with limited exceptions). Test MATERIALS are protected and NOT released to clients to maintain test security. When a court orders release of test materials, the psychologist should make reasonable efforts to maintain test security while complying with the order, such as requesting that the court limit access to qualified professionals
questions.modified_passage: Key Distinction for the EPPP: Test DATA is generally released to clients upon request (with limited exceptions). Test MATERIALS are protected and NOT released to clients to maintain test security. When a court orders release of test materials, the psychologist should make reasonable efforts to maintain test validity while complying with the order, such as requesting that the court limit access to qualified professionals
options: The passage incorrectly states that test DATA is released to clients; it should say test MATERIALS are released to clients
The passage incorrectly states that the court should limit access to qualified professionals; it should say limit access to licensed psychologists only
The passage incorrectly states the psychologist should maintain test validity; it should say maintain test security
The passage incorrectly states that test MATERIALS are NOT released to clients; it should say test MATERIALS are released only with informed consent
questions.explanation: The passage was modified to say 'maintain test validity' when the correct concern is 'maintain test security.' According to APA Ethics Code Standard 9.11 and related standards, when a court orders release of test materials, the psychologist's obligation is to make reasonable efforts to maintain TEST SECURITY — that is, to prevent the materials from becoming publicly available and compromising the integrity of the test for future use. While test validity is an important psychometric concept, the specific ethical obligation in this context pertains to test security.

questions.original_passage: Disulfiram mechanism: Inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, causing accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed, resulting in nausea, flushing, headache. This is aversive conditioning — not pharmacological craving reduction.
questions.modified_passage: Disulfiram mechanism: Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase, causing accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed, resulting in nausea, flushing, headache. This is aversive conditioning — not pharmacological craving reduction.
options: The passage incorrectly states the mechanism is 'aversive conditioning'; it should say 'operant conditioning'
The passage incorrectly states 'alcohol dehydrogenase'; it should say 'aldehyde dehydrogenase'
The passage incorrectly states that acetaldehyde accumulates; it should say that ethanol accumulates
The passage incorrectly states 'not pharmacological craving reduction'; it should say 'not classical conditioning'
questions.explanation: Disulfiram (Antabuse) works by inhibiting aldehyde dehydrogenase, the enzyme responsible for breaking down acetaldehyde (a toxic metabolite of alcohol). The passage incorrectly substitutes 'alcohol dehydrogenase,' which is a different enzyme that converts ethanol into acetaldehyde. By blocking aldehyde dehydrogenase, disulfiram causes acetaldehyde to accumulate, producing the unpleasant symptoms (nausea, flushing, headache) that serve as the basis for aversive conditioning against alcohol consumption.

questions.original_passage: The clinician wants to estimate cognitive ability without the confound of processing speed deficits
questions.modified_passage: The clinician wants to estimate cognitive ability without the confound of working memory deficits

questions.explanation: The General Ability Index (GAI) is specifically designed to estimate cognitive ability while removing the influence of both processing speed and working memory. However, the original passage specifically mentions processing speed deficits as the confound the clinician wants to avoid. The modified passage incorrectly substituted 'working memory deficits' for 'processing speed deficits.' While the GAI does exclude both Working Memory and Processing Speed subtests, the original passage specifically referenced processing speed deficits as the confound in question.

questions.original_passage: Aphasia Screening Test: Part of the HRNB; screens for language disturbances associated with dominant (typically left) hemisphere dysfunction
questions.modified_passage: Aphasia Screening Test: Part of the HRNB; screens for language disturbances associated with non-dominant (typically right) hemisphere dysfunction

questions.explanation: The Aphasia Screening Test screens for language disturbances associated with dominant (typically left) hemisphere dysfunction, not non-dominant (typically right) hemisphere dysfunction. Language functions are predominantly lateralized to the left hemisphere in most individuals, which is the dominant hemisphere for language. The passage incorrectly reversed this to 'non-dominant (typically right)' hemisphere.

questions.explanation: The key early task in IPT is called the 'interpersonal inventory,' not the 'interpersonal formulation.' The interpersonal inventory is a detailed review of the client's significant relationships — their patterns, expectations, satisfying and unsatisfying aspects, and changes the client desires. 'Interpersonal formulation' sounds plausible because 'formulation' is a common clinical term, but it is not the correct name for this specific IPT technique.

questions.original_passage: KABC-II Luria model: Excludes Knowledge/Gc scale. Yields Mental Processing Index. Preferred for culturally/linguistically diverse examinees to avoid confounding cognitive processing with acquired knowledge.
questions.modified_passage: KABC-II Luria model: Excludes Knowledge/Gc scale. Yields Fluid-Crystallized Index. Preferred for culturally/linguistically diverse examinees to avoid confounding cognitive processing with acquired knowledge.
options: The passage incorrectly states the model is preferred for culturally/linguistically diverse examinees; it should say it is preferred for examinees with learning disabilities

The passage incorrectly states the index yielded is the 'Fluid-Crystallized Index'; it should say 'Mental Processing Index'
The passage incorrectly states it avoids confounding cognitive processing with acquired knowledge; it should say it avoids confounding fluid reasoning with working memory
questions.explanation: The KABC-II Luria model yields the Mental Processing Index (MPI), not the 'Fluid-Crystallized Index.' The Fluid-Crystallized Index (FCI) is the composite score associated with the CHC model of the KABC-II, which includes the Knowledge/Gc scale. The Luria model specifically excludes Knowledge/Gc and produces the MPI, making it more appropriate for culturally and linguistically diverse examinees.

questions.original_passage: Informed consent is replaced by notification of purpose when the evaluation is court-ordered
questions.modified_passage: Informed consent is replaced by notification of purpose when the evaluation is self-referred.
options: The passage incorrectly states 'informed consent'; it should say 'informed assent'
The passage incorrectly states 'notification of purpose'; it should say 'notification of rights'
The passage incorrectly states 'self-referred'; it should say 'court-ordered'
The passage incorrectly states 'replaced by'; it should say 'supplemented by'
questions.explanation: The passage incorrectly states that informed consent is replaced by notification of purpose when the evaluation is 'self-referred.' In reality, informed consent is replaced by notification of purpose when the evaluation is 'court-ordered.' In self-referred evaluations, standard informed consent procedures still apply. It is specifically in court-ordered or mandated evaluations where the psychologist cannot obtain true informed consent (because the examinee has no choice about participating), so the ethical standard requires that the psychologist instead provide a notification of purpose explaining the nature and purpose of the evaluation.

questions.original_passage: MBSR vs. MBCT: MBSR = Kabat-Zinn, general stress/pain, transdiagnostic. MBCT = Segal/Williams/Teasdale, depression relapse prevention, includes CBT-specific content.
questions.modified_passage: MBSR vs. MBCT: MBSR = Kabat-Zinn, general stress/pain, transdiagnostic. MBCT = Segal/Williams/Teasdale, depression relapse prevention, includes DBT-specific content.

questions.explanation: The passage was modified to say MBCT includes 'DBT-specific content,' but MBCT (Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy) actually incorporates CBT-specific content (cognitive behavioral therapy elements) combined with mindfulness practices. DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy) is a separate treatment approach developed by Marsha Linehan, primarily associated with borderline personality disorder treatment, and is not what MBCT integrates.

questions.original_passage: Court-ordered evaluations: When the evaluation is ordered by the court, privilege typically does not apply because the relationship is not therapeutic
questions.modified_passage: Court-ordered evaluations: When the evaluation is ordered by the court, privilege typically does not apply because the relationship is not voluntary

questions.explanation: The original passage states that privilege does not apply to court-ordered evaluations because the relationship is not 'therapeutic.' The modified passage changed 'therapeutic' to 'voluntary.' While the involuntary nature of court-ordered evaluations may be a related consideration, the key legal reason privilege does not apply is specifically because the relationship formed during a court-ordered evaluation is not a therapeutic one — it is an evaluative or forensic relationship, which is fundamentally different from a treatment relationship that privilege is designed to protect.

questions.original_passage: Incremental validity: The key question for projective tests — do they add predictive value beyond objective measures?
questions.modified_passage: Incremental validity: The key question for projective tests — do they add predictive value beyond structured interviews?
options: The passage incorrectly states 'predictive value'; it should say 'diagnostic value'
The passage incorrectly states 'incremental validity'; it should say 'convergent validity'
The passage incorrectly states 'structured interviews'; it should say 'objective measures'
The passage incorrectly states 'projective tests'; it should say 'performance-based tests'
questions.explanation: The passage was modified to replace 'objective measures' with 'structured interviews.' Incremental validity in the context of projective testing specifically asks whether projective tests add predictive value beyond what is already provided by objective measures (e.g., self-report inventories like the MMPI). While structured interviews are a valid assessment method, the classic incremental validity question for projective tests is framed in comparison to objective personality measures.

questions.original_passage: Flooding: Prolonged exposure to most feared stimulus. No relaxation component. Relies on habituation.
questions.modified_passage: Flooding: Prolonged exposure to most feared stimulus. No relaxation component. Relies on sensitization.
options: The passage incorrectly states 'prolonged exposure'; it should say 'brief exposure'
The passage incorrectly states 'most feared stimulus'; it should say 'least feared stimulus'
The passage incorrectly states 'sensitization'; it should say 'habituation'
The passage incorrectly states 'no relaxation component'; it should say 'includes a relaxation component'
questions.explanation: Flooding relies on habituation — the gradual decrease in response to a stimulus after prolonged, repeated exposure. The passage incorrectly substituted 'sensitization,' which is actually the opposite process (an increased response to a stimulus over time). Flooding works because the client remains in the presence of the feared stimulus long enough for anxiety to naturally decrease through habituation, not sensitization.

questions.original_passage: The Sick Role in IPT: Early in treatment, the IPT therapist formally assigns the "sick role" — acknowledging that the client has a legitimate illness (depression) that is not their fault. This serves to reduce guilt and self-blame, normalize the client's difficulties, and mobilize the client to work toward recovery as they would with any medical illness. This is one of IPT's most distinctive features

This is one of CBT's most distinctive features.
options: The passage incorrectly states the sick role is assigned 'early in treatment'; it should say 'in the middle phase of treatment'
The passage incorrectly states that the sick role reduces 'guilt and self-blame'; it should say 'anxiety and avoidance'
The passage incorrectly states this is one of 'CBT's most distinctive features'; it should say 'IPT's most distinctive features'

questions.explanation: The passage incorrectly attributes the sick role as a distinctive feature of CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy) when it is actually a distinctive feature of IPT (Interpersonal Therapy). The sick role concept — in which the therapist explicitly acknowledges the client's depression as a legitimate medical illness — is a hallmark of IPT, not CBT. CBT focuses on identifying and modifying cognitive distortions and maladaptive behaviors, and does not employ the formal sick role assignment as part of its framework.

questions.original_passage: RFT: Relational Frame Theory — ACT's theoretical foundation. A behavioral account of how language creates suffering through cognitive fusion.
questions.modified_passage: RFT: Relational Frame Theory — ACT's theoretical foundation. A cognitive account of how language creates suffering through cognitive fusion.

The passage incorrectly states 'cognitive fusion'; it should say 'cognitive defusion'
The passage incorrectly describes RFT as 'a cognitive account'; it should say 'a behavioral account'
The passage incorrectly states that RFT is ACT's theoretical foundation; it should say it is DBT's theoretical foundation
questions.explanation: Relational Frame Theory (RFT) is fundamentally a behavioral account of human language and cognition, rooted in functional contextualism and behavior analysis. The passage was modified to say 'cognitive account,' which mischaracterizes its theoretical orientation. RFT specifically provides a behavioral (not cognitive) explanation of how language and relational responding lead to psychological suffering through processes like cognitive fusion. This distinction is important because ACT is classified as a 'third-wave' behavior therapy, and its theoretical underpinning in RFT is explicitly behavioral in nature.

questions.original_passage: EPPP Note: The PPVT is a measure of receptive vocabulary only, not overall intelligence. Using it as a sole estimate of IQ would overrepresent crystallized verbal ability and miss fluid reasoning, processing speed, working memory, and visual-spatial abilities
questions.modified_passage: EPPP Note: The PPVT is a measure of receptive vocabulary only, not overall intelligence. Using it as a sole estimate of IQ would overrepresent fluid verbal ability and miss crystallized reasoning, processing speed, working memory, and visual-spatial abilities

The passage incorrectly states 'visual-spatial abilities'; it should say 'perceptual reasoning abilities'

questions.explanation: The passage swapped the Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) terms 'crystallized' and 'fluid.' The PPVT measures receptive vocabulary, which is a component of crystallized intelligence (Gc). Therefore, using the PPVT as a sole IQ estimate would overrepresent crystallized (not fluid) verbal ability and would miss fluid reasoning (Gf), along with processing speed, working memory, and visual-spatial abilities. The modified passage reversed these two key terms.

questions.original_passage: Comparing SEM and SEE: SEM uses reliability (r xx ) and tells us about measurement precision of a single score. questions.modified_passage: Comparing SEM and SEE: SEM uses reliability (r xx ) and tells us about measurement precision of a single score. SEE uses validity (r xy 2 ) and tells us about prediction precision from one variable to another. Both are smaller when the relevant correlation is higher — higher reliability means smaller SEM; higher validity means smaller SEM
options: The passage incorrectly states that SEM uses reliability (r xx ); it should say validity (r xy 2 )
The passage incorrectly states that SEE tells us about prediction precision; it should say measurement precision
The passage incorrectly states that higher validity means smaller SEM; it should say higher validity means smaller SEE
The passage incorrectly states that both are smaller when the relevant correlation is higher; it should say both are larger when the relevant correlation is higher
questions.explanation: The final clause of the passage was altered to read 'higher validity means smaller SEM' instead of the correct 'higher validity means smaller SEE.' SEM (Standard Error of Measurement) is associated with reliability, while SEE (Standard Error of Estimate) is associated with validity. Higher validity coefficients produce a smaller SEE, not a smaller SEM. The error subtly swaps the acronym at the end of the passage, making it inconsistent with the correct distinction between these two concepts.

questions.explanation: The minus sign (-) in the profile notation 'N-' indicates a weakness, not a strength. The original passage correctly states that 'N- indicates nonverbal weakness,' but the modified passage erroneously changed 'weakness' to 'strength.' In standard score profile interpretation, a '+' sign denotes a relative strength and a '-' sign denotes a relative weakness in that domain.

questions.original_passage: Response style: Social desirability, malingering, acquiescence, random responding. All objective tests include validity scales to detect these. Projective tests assess through behavioral observation and protocol variables.
questions.modified_passage: Response style: Social desirability, malingering, acquiescence, random responding. All objective tests include reliability scales to detect these. Projective tests assess through behavioral observation and protocol variables.

The passage incorrectly lists 'malingering' as a response style; it should say 'impression management'
questions.explanation: The passage was modified to say 'reliability scales' instead of 'validity scales.' Objective personality tests (such as the MMPI-2) include validity scales (e.g., L, F, K scales) specifically designed to detect response styles such as social desirability, malingering, acquiescence, and random responding. Reliability scales measure consistency of measurement over time or across items, which is a different psychometric concept. The other options describe changes that were not actually made to the passage.

questions.original_passage: ABPP: Board certification beyond licensure. Available in specialty areas. Requires peer review of work samples.
questions.modified_passage: ABPP: Board certification beyond licensure. Available in specialty areas. Requires supervisor review of work samples.

questions.explanation: The passage was modified to say 'supervisor review of work samples' when in fact ABPP board certification requires 'peer review' of work samples. Peer review — evaluation by fellow professionals at a similar level of expertise — is a hallmark of the ABPP credentialing process. Supervisor review implies an evaluative hierarchy that does not accurately describe the ABPP process. The other options describe changes that were not actually made to the passage.

questions.original_passage: ACT: Hayes. Psychological flexibility (not symptom reduction) is the goal. Six core processes in hexaflex model. Third-wave CBT approach.
questions.modified_passage: ACT: Hayes. Psychological flexibility (not symptom reduction) is the goal. Six core processes in hexaflex model. Second-wave CBT approach.
options: The passage incorrectly states the goal is psychological flexibility; it should say cognitive defusion
The passage incorrectly states ACT is a Second-wave CBT approach; it should say Third-wave CBT approach
The passage incorrectly attributes ACT to Hayes; it should attribute it to Linehan
The passage incorrectly states there are six core processes; it should say five core processes
questions.explanation: ACT (Acceptance and Commitment Therapy) is classified as a third-wave CBT approach, not a second-wave approach. Second-wave CBT refers to traditional cognitive-behavioral therapies (e.g., Beck's cognitive therapy, Ellis's REBT). Third-wave approaches, including ACT, DBT, and MBCT, emphasize processes such as acceptance, mindfulness, and psychological flexibility rather than direct cognitive restructuring. The passage was modified to say 'Second-wave' instead of the correct 'Third-wave.'

questions.original_passage: A case formulation is a hypothesis about the causes, precipitants, and maintaining factors of an individual's psychological problems. It goes beyond diagnosis to provide a conceptual framework for treatment. Components typically include:
questions.modified_passage: A case formulation is a hypothesis about the causes, precipitants, and maintaining factors of an individual's psychological problems. It goes beyond assessment to provide a conceptual framework for treatment. Components typically include:
options: The passage incorrectly states 'conceptual framework'; it should say 'theoretical framework'
The passage incorrectly states 'maintaining factors'; it should say 'perpetuating factors'
The passage incorrectly states 'beyond assessment'; it should say 'beyond diagnosis'
The passage incorrectly states 'hypothesis'; it should say 'theory'
questions.explanation: The original passage states that a case formulation 'goes beyond diagnosis to provide a conceptual framework for treatment.' In the modified passage, 'diagnosis' was changed to 'assessment,' which is incorrect. A case formulation is specifically described as going beyond diagnosis — not assessment — because while a diagnosis classifies a disorder, a case formulation provides an individualized understanding of the specific mechanisms causing and maintaining a patient's problems. Assessment is actually a broader process that can include case formulation itself, so saying a case formulation goes beyond assessment would be conceptually inaccurate.

questions.original_passage: WISC-V: Ages 6-16. Five indices (VCI, VSI, FRI, WMI, PSI). Separates Visual Spatial from Fluid Reasoning. Includes Picture Span for visual working memory
questions.modified_passage: WISC-V: Ages 6-16. Five indices (VCI, VSI, FRI, WMI, PSI). Separates Visual Spatial from Fluid Reasoning. Includes Picture Span for visual long-term memory

questions.explanation: The original passage correctly states that Picture Span is a subtest for visual working memory. The modified passage changed 'working memory' to 'long-term memory,' which is incorrect. Picture Span is part of the Working Memory Index (WMI) on the WISC-V and specifically measures visual working memory, not visual long-term memory.

questions.original_passage: Competence in administering a test does not automatically confer competence in interpreting it (and vice versa)
questions.modified_passage: Competence in administering a test automatically confers competence in interpreting it (and vice versa)
options: The passage incorrectly states that competence in administering a test 'automatically confers' competence in interpreting it; it should state that it 'does not automatically confer' competence in interpreting it

questions.explanation: The original passage states that competence in administering a test does NOT automatically confer competence in interpreting it. The modified passage reverses this critical ethical principle by removing 'does not,' making it appear that administration competence equals interpretation competence. This is a concept reversal error that contradicts a fundamental principle in assessment ethics: administration skills and interpretation skills are distinct competencies, and possessing one does not guarantee the other.

questions.modified_sentence: Clinical norms are based on samples of individuals with specific diagnoses or presenting problems, are important for distinguishing among clinical groups, and differ from standardization norms which are based on a representative sample of a specific age cohort.
phrases: Clinical norms are based on samples of individuals with specific diagnoses or presenting problems,
are important for distinguishing among clinical groups,
and differ from standardization norms which are based on a representative sample
of a specific age cohort.
questions.explanation: Standardization norms (also called national or standard norms) are based on a representative sample of the general population, not a specific age cohort. Clinical norms, by contrast, are based on samples of individuals with specific diagnoses or presenting problems. The distinction between these two types of norms is fundamental to psychometric test interpretation.

questions.section: Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales, Third Edition (Vineland-3)
questions.modified_sentence: The Vineland-3 yields an Adaptive Behavior Composite (ABC) and domain standard scores (M = 100, SD = 15), and it is primarily administered via structured clinical interview with a caregiver or respondent who knows the individual well.
phrases: The Vineland-3 yields an Adaptive Behavior Composite (ABC) and domain standard scores (M = 100, SD = 15),
and it is primarily administered via structured clinical interview
with a caregiver or respondent
who knows the individual well.
questions.explanation: The Vineland-3 is administered via a semi-structured interview, not a structured clinical interview. The semi-structured format allows the interviewer flexibility to probe and follow up on responses from the caregiver, rather than following a rigid, fully structured protocol. The term 'structured clinical interview' is associated with other instruments such as the SCID, not the Vineland-3.

questions.modified_sentence: The MMPI-2 consists of 567 true/false items and yields scores on 10 clinical scales, 3 traditional validity scales, and numerous supplementary and content scales, with clinical scale scores reported as T-scores (M = 50, SD = 10) and scores at or above T = 70 considered clinically significant.

questions.error_original: at or above T = 70 considered clinically significant
questions.error_correct: at or above T = 65 considered clinically significant
questions.explanation: On the MMPI-2, the cutoff for clinical significance is a T-score of 65, not 70. The T = 70 cutoff was used on the original MMPI, but when the MMPI-2 was developed, the clinical significance threshold was lowered to T = 65 using uniform T-scores for most clinical scales.

questions.modified_sentence: The Children's Apperception Test (CAT) is Leopold Bellak's adaptation of the TAT for children ages 3-10, featuring animal figures in anthropomorphic situations rather than human figures, based on the assumption that young children identify more readily with animals than people, and a human figure version called the CAT-P is also available.

questions.modified_sentence: The AUDIT is a WHO-developed 10-item alcohol screening tool that distinguishes hazardous from dependent drinking and is considered more comprehensive than the CAGE questionnaire.

questions.explanation: The AUDIT (Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test) was designed to distinguish hazardous from harmful drinking patterns, not hazardous from dependent drinking. questions.section: Advantages of Structured and Semi-Structured Interviews

Intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs) are used for continuous measures, not categorical diagnostic agreement.

Super's original fifth stage is specifically termed 'decline,' which refers to the period of deceleration, retirement planning, and retirement living that occurs in late adulthood.

questions.modified_sentence: CRA (Community Reinforcement Approach) is a comprehensive behavioral approach that rearranges vocational, social, family, and recreational contingencies so that a substance-using lifestyle is more punishing rather than making a sober lifestyle more rewarding than substance use.

questions.modified_sentence: Contingency management applies operant conditioning principles by providing tangible reinforcers (typically vouchers redeemable for goods and services) for objectively verified drug-free urine samples or treatment attendance, and the voucher value typically increases with consecutive drug-free samples and resets to the initial value after a negative sample.

The term 'positive reinforcement trap' is incorrect; the key mechanism is negative reinforcement, where both parties escape an aversive stimulus.

questions.section: CBT-E for Bulimia and Binge Eating
questions.modified_sentence: In CBT-E developed by Fairburn, cognitive restructuring targets the overvaluation of shape and weight, which is conceptualized as a core predisposing factor, and also addresses rigid dietary rules that perpetuate the binge-purge cycle.

The distinction is critical: CBT-E is based on a maintenance model that identifies factors keeping the disorder going in the present, rather than factors that originally caused or predisposed the individual to the disorder. Targeting maintaining mechanisms is what drives therapeutic change in CBT-E.

questions.section: Structure of Beck's CBT for Depression
questions.modified_sentence: Late sessions in Beck's CBT for depression (sessions 13-20) focus on identifying and modifying core beliefs or schemas, implementing relapse prevention strategies, spacing sessions to promote dependence, and consolidating gains achieved during earlier phases of treatment.

The goal is to help clients function autonomously using the skills they have learned, reducing their reliance on the therapist as treatment comes to an end.

questions.modified_sentence: Symbol Search is a visual scanning task where the examinee determines whether a target symbol matches any symbol in a search group, and it measures processing speed and auditory discrimination.

phrases: Standard scores, such as z-scores,

questions.modified_sentence: The act of self-monitoring itself tends to change the behavior being monitored — typically in a countertherapeutic direction (e.g., smokers who record each cigarette tend to smoke less), and this reactivity effect is actually beneficial in clinical interventions but compromises accuracy for assessment purposes.

questions.explanation: Self-monitoring reactivity typically changes behavior in a therapeutic (desirable) direction, not a countertherapeutic one. Replacing 'therapeutic' with 'countertherapeutic' creates an error that contradicts the established finding, though the example in the same phrase (smoking less) could serve as a subtle contextual clue for attentive readers.

questions.modified_sentence: The HCR-20 is a structured professional judgment tool that integrates Historical, Community, and Risk Management domains, and allows clinical judgment in the final risk determination.

escape or extinction, access to tangibles, and sensory stimulation.
questions.explanation: The four primary functions of behavior identified in FBA research are: (1) attention seeking, (2) escape or avoidance, (3) access to tangibles, and (4) sensory stimulation (automatic reinforcement). 'Extinction' is a behavioral procedure used to reduce behavior, not one of the four functions. The correct term is 'escape or avoidance,' meaning the behavior functions to allow the individual to escape or avoid aversive stimuli or demands.

questions.modified_sentence: Functional analysis is a core component of cognitive-behavioral coping skills training, which involves identifying the reinforcers or triggers, the behaviors such as substance use, and the consequences that maintain the addiction cycle.
phrases: Functional analysis is a core component of cognitive-behavioral coping skills training,
which involves identifying the reinforcers or triggers,
the behaviors such as substance use,
and the consequences that maintain the addiction cycle.
questions.explanation: In functional analysis within cognitive-behavioral coping skills training, the ABC model identifies Antecedents (triggers), Behaviors (substance use), and Consequences. 'Reinforcers' is incorrect here — the correct term is 'antecedents,' which refers to the situational triggers that precede substance use. Reinforcers would fall under consequences, not the 'A' component of the model.

questions.modified_sentence: Cultural humility is an ongoing process of self-reflection and openness to learning, while cultural competence implies an achievable endpoint, and current emphasis in the field favors competence over humility as the preferred framework.
phrases: Cultural humility is an ongoing process of self-reflection and openness to learning,
while cultural competence implies an achievable endpoint,
and current emphasis in the field
favors competence over humility as the preferred framework.
questions.error_original: favors competence over humility as the preferred framework
questions.error_correct: favors humility over competence as the preferred framework
questions.explanation: The passage states that current emphasis favors humility, not competence. Cultural humility, with its emphasis on ongoing self-reflection and acknowledgment of one's limitations, is currently favored over cultural competence, which implies a finite endpoint that can be fully achieved. The error reverses which approach is currently preferred in the field.

questions.modified_sentence: The Halstead-Reitan Impairment Index is a summary score ranging from 0.0 to 1.0, representing the proportion of tests falling in the impaired range, and a cutoff of 0.5 is used to suggest the presence of brain dysfunction.
phrases: The Halstead-Reitan Impairment Index is a summary score ranging from 0.0 to 1.0,
representing the proportion of tests falling in the impaired range,
and a cutoff of 0.5 is used to suggest
the presence of brain dysfunction.
questions.explanation: The Halstead-Reitan Impairment Index uses a cutoff of 0.4 (not 0.5) to suggest the presence of brain dysfunction. Scores at or above 0.4 indicate that a sufficient proportion of the battery's tests fall in the impaired range to warrant concern about brain dysfunction.

sentences: The Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence, Fourth Edition includes age-appropriate subtests for younger children.
For ages 2:6 to 3:11, only three index scores are available (VCI, VSI, FSI).
For ages 4:0 to 7:7, the full five-index structure is available.
Notable subtests include Bug Search, Picture Memory, and Zoo Locations.
questions.original_sentence: For ages 2:6 to 3:11, only three index scores are available (VCI, VSI, WMI).
questions.explanation: For the younger age band (2:6–3:11) of the WPPSI-IV, the three available index scores are the Verbal Comprehension Index (VCI), Visual Spatial Index (VSI), and Working Memory Index (WMI). The error substituted 'FSI' (Full Scale Index, which is not one of the three primary index scores for this age band) for 'WMI.'

questions.section: Standard 9.08: Obsolete Tests and Outdated Results
sentences: Psychologists do not base their assessment decisions or recommendations on data from tests that are obsolete or outdated for the current purpose.
Test norms become outdated due to the Flynn effect — the well-documented increase in IQ scores over time (approximately 3 points per decade).
Using old norms can overestimate abilities and result in missed diagnoses, particularly for intellectual disability.
When newer editions of a test are available, clinicians should use the most current version unless a specific reason justifies the older edition.
questions.original_sentence: Using old norms can overestimate abilities and result in missed diagnoses, particularly for intellectual disability.
questions.error_correct: overestimate abilities is actually correct — the intended error is different. Let me reconsider.
questions.explanation: Placeholder — regenerating.

sentences: Many individually administered tests use basal and ceiling rules to determine starting and stopping points.
The basal is established when the examinee achieves a specified number of consecutive correct responses, and all items below the basal are credited as correct.
The ceiling is established when the examinee fails a specified number of consecutive items, and testing stops.
Understanding these rules is important because violations (e.g., starting too low or stopping too early) can invalidate scores.
Some tests (e.g., WISC-V) use discontinue rules rather than traditional basal/ceiling rules.
questions.original_sentence: Understanding these rules is important because violations (e.g., starting too high or stopping too early) can invalidate scores.
questions.explanation: A common basal rule violation occurs when the examiner starts at an item that is too high (too difficult) for the examinee, potentially failing to establish a basal. The passage was changed from 'starting too high' to 'starting too low,' which would not typically be a problematic violation — starting too low simply means administering easier items the examinee would likely pass, which wastes time but is less likely to invalidate scores.

questions.section: Grade Equivalents, Age Equivalents, and Their Limitations
sentences: Misinterpretation Example: A third-grader obtains a grade equivalent of 6.2 on a reading comprehension test.
This does NOT mean the child reads at a sixth-grade level.
It means the child performed as well as the average beginning-sixth-grader would be predicted to perform ON third-grade content.
The child has not been exposed to sixth-grade material, and the score is typically interpolated rather than based on actual data from sixth-graders taking the third-grade test.
questions.original_sentence: The child has not been exposed to sixth-grade material, and the score is typically extrapolated rather than based on actual data from sixth-graders taking the third-grade test.
questions.explanation: The original passage correctly states that grade equivalent scores beyond the tested range are 'extrapolated' (estimated beyond available data points). The error substituted 'interpolated,' which refers to estimating values within a range of known data points. In psychometrics, grade equivalents at the extremes are derived through extrapolation, not interpolation, because the normative data typically does not include students from those grade levels actually taking the test.

sentences: Privilege vs. Confidentiality: Confidentiality is a broader ethical obligation to protect client information from disclosure.
Privilege is a narrower legal right that protects against compelled disclosure in judicial proceedings.
A communication can be confidential but not privileged (e.g., a therapist could be legally compelled to testify), or both confidential and privileged.
Privilege is established by ethical codes or case law and varies by jurisdiction.
